channel.title: Root Network Security
channel.description: Beginners's journey through the world of security, programming and system administration. In love with GNU/Linux and cryptography.

item.title: AngstromCTF - slots
item.description:
In this challenge I‚Äôm going to show how focusing on only one attack vector may make you fail hard.

  • Category: Misc
  • Points: 90

Solution

At the beginning, we‚Äôre given a source of an application running on certain port web.angstromctf.com:3002. By connecting to this port using nc, we‚Äôre given a simple blackjack game, taking an user bet and then making the random choice.

But as we have the source code, let‚Äôs take a look at it.

From the start we can see that the input is converting our numbers to float with bet = float(bet), then it performs checks that will determine whether the numbers isn‚Äôt smaller than 0, and if it‚Äôs not bigger than our current money status.

After that the application will generate three lines, with the second/middle one used to generate our outcome.

But as the random number generator isn‚Äôt seeded with any value, the sequence of values should be the same for each run of this program. That‚Äôs what I decided to dig into and check whether or not it‚Äôs correct. Below are the sample three 3 games.

As you can see, values do not change with each game. That made me feel confident and that‚Äôs how I stopped further analyzing code and decided to dig into this problem, writing python script that will bet very small amounts of money in order to check where it‚Äôs possible to win some money. In quick words - bad idea.

That‚Äôs why:

This loop will iterate as long as we‚Äôre able to win something, making sure that it‚Äôs impossible to win from any combo in this game. Banging my head after such a stupid mistake, I decided to look for something else in this code and in Python documentation about float() function I‚Äôve noticed something interesting.

Interesting, let‚Äôs check the NaN value, as the -+inf will be blocked by the boundary checks.

item.title: Vulnhub.com - Bob 1
item.description:
Welcome back to another machine from Vulnhub called Bob 1.

  • Author: c0rruptedb1t
  • Download: http://c0rruptedb1t.ddns.net/vms/bob.html

Solution

As always we have to get the IP address of the vulnerable machine. Here we can see that it‚Äôs sitting on 10.0.2.4 address, with 2 open ports - ftp and http.

So we can just go straight to the http service, but in the same time, I decided to run more complex nmap scan that will cover all ports.

But to the website.

After viewing some of the sub pages, I‚Äôve noticed a comment in the source code.

In order to enumerate as much as possible, I decided to also note down content from the contact page.

And login page.

While looking at some of these notes, the previously started nmap scan has just ended. Let‚Äôs take a look at the results.

As you can see, it discovered quite a few things in the webpage, together with a new open port - 25468 running ssh service. Let‚Äôs note that down and move forward.

As the scan showed us that there is robots.txt file, we can take a look at it.

Now we can look at each of these pages. Firstly - passwords.

Memo web page.

And finally a dev shell page, containing another comment.

I quickly noticed that there was no possibility to run any commands. But after a few moments there it was, a possibility to run echo command.

After that I checked eval command and to my amusement, it works!

Do you see .hint file? Let‚Äôs view it.

Now we‚Äôre certain that the best option would be to create a reverse shell using netcat.

Great, we have it! Let‚Äôs play around and see what files we can find interesting. Firstly, I decide to take a look at the source code of the shell.

Then I went straight into the user home directories. Let‚Äôs see them.

We can start with Bob as he‚Äôs our hero today.

Great, we have the passwords! Now let‚Äôs look for more clues.

There‚Äôs a lot of these files, but I don‚Äôt think they‚Äôll be any useful. Let‚Äôs keep looking.

Hmm, that‚Äôs interesing. But at this moment, I decided to use previously obtain passwords and log in using ssh.

Why we can‚Äôt use cat command. Luckily less is not blocked.

As I remember something about Bob‚Äôs strange wallpaper policy, I decided to look for such and check for any hidden information.

We can copy it using scp.

But that was false alarm as nothing was there. And that‚Äôs when I decided to go back to Bob. In the Documents directory that was something else that I missed during the first time.

Seems like James was the only sane member of this group :D

What‚Äôs that!? Let‚Äôs leave this for later and copy previously noticed login.txt.gpg file.

But of course we‚Äôre going to need a pasword in order to decrypt the login. That‚Äôs when I started looking at all my previous notes but none of the guesses worked. And here comes the notes.sh and the first letters of each sentence - HARPOCRATES. That‚Äôs the password.

Now, we can login into Bob‚Äôs account.

And of course, as he‚Äôs admin, we can change our privilages into the root.

item.title: Pwnable.kr - cmd1
item.description:
Welcome to the next challenge called cmd1 from pwnable.kr.

Solution

Firstly, as usual, we‚Äôre going to log into the provided ssh server.

Now we‚Äôre ready to view the source code of the provided challenge files.

First thing that is ready to exploit is that if we provide correct argument, program will put it to the system() function that will run the code. But the first obstacle is that the input is being filtered through the filter() function that will stop execution if the passed argument contains words like flag, sh or tmp.

So we need to enter something along the lines of cat flag, but that of course will not execute. But finding that running only cat program fails, made me think more about the putenv() function.

If we view the PATH environment variables, we can see that the list contains all directories where the binaries are located.

So the program overwriting this, will force us to enter the whole path of cat binary.

One thing solved. Now we have to somehow obfuscate the flag word in a way that filter will not catch.

Luckily, this simple quotation trick makes this challenge marked as solved.

item.title: Pwnable.kr - lotto
item.description:
Another challenge, another mistake in code. Lotto challenge from pwnable.kr.

Solution

Let‚Äôs log in into provided ssh server and as we have the executable, run the file.

So that‚Äôs another guessing game. We can look at help option to look for hints.

To be honest, that‚Äôs not much here so let‚Äôs get into the code.

Firstly, we notice that unsigned char lotto[6]; is a char variable, so only printable characters. As this lotto takes only numbers in range 1-45, it leaves us with the range of 33 - 45. Looking at the ASCII table, characters with these codes are !"#$%&'()*+,-.

But after that, we can also notice another bug.

These piece of code means that for each character in the lotto, it will iterate every character in the input. So we can just enter any possible character six times, and with a little bit of luck, we‚Äôll get the match and win the game.

item.title: EasyCTF 2018 - My Letter
item.description:
This time we‚Äôre walking through the challenge called My Letter from the forenscics category.

  • Category: Forensics
  • Points: 80

You can find full problem info here, together with the original file.

Solution

Firstly, let‚Äôs view the file with a docx viewer like Libre Office Writer.

As you can see, some of the letters are bolded. Let‚Äôs delete the rest and see what we‚Äôll get.

Just a troll :D

But let‚Äôs remember that docx is actually made of a zip, so let‚Äôs change the into my_letter.zip and unpack it. Maybe its content will show us the flag?

An image? Let‚Äôs take a look.

Tools

Libre Office Writer

References

http://www.forensicswiki.org/wiki/Word_Document_(DOCX)

item.title: EasyCTF 2018 - Not OTP
item.description:
Today we‚Äôre going through cryptography challenge from EasyCTF called Not OTP.

  • Category: Crypto
  • Points: 100

In addition we get a hint telling us that there‚Äôs something about the cribs.

Solution

As the hint is about cribs, I decided to firstly use an attack called crib dragging, which works only when two messages are encrypted (xored as in OTP) using the same key. AS you probably know, OTP is only safe when each message has it‚Äôs own, unique key.

But back to the attack. To make sure the attack will work, we have to know some of the plaintext from one of the messages. It may be part of the flag, most common English words etc. Firstly, we xor two messages together. Then we xor the suspected plaintext with the xored messages, but at each position of the messages. If this operation produces some readable English text, we may suspect that the plaintext was a part of the message.

Now as we know the basics, let‚Äôs get into the task.

To make solution easier and the process of attacking faster, I decided to use a ready tool called CribDrag made by Daniel Crowley. Thanks!

From now we‚Äôre ready to attack both ciphertexts. Firstly, we‚Äôll have to xor them with each other but luckily, CribDrag has separate script to do this.

Now let‚Äôs the output and run it in cribdrag.

Now the guessing part! Firstly, we know that the message will contain easyctf{ part as it‚Äôs part of the flag.

In one of this parts we see text that highly looks like part of the English sentence. Let‚Äôs take it‚Äôs position and place in the mesage.

My next guess was word flag. Will it be a good one?

Now we can see that it‚Äôs getting more readable. After that we‚Äôre ready to add is , but to make more readable strings, I decided to input whole flag is easyctf{.

After that part I was stuck for a while. I had no clue what to put there next, trying some random different characters until I noticed that there should be a space also before the flag word. This simple operation will add another letter into the key, which may help us find the right crib.

But no luck for me. After that part, my team mate proposed a word sample, which gave pretty good results.

Lastly, after quite some time we were able to slowly reveal some parts of the message and key.

Tools

https://github.com/SpiderLabs/cribdrag

References

https://travisdazell.blogspot.com/2012/11/many-time-pad-attack-crib-drag.html

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Known-plaintext_attack

item.title: Pwnable.kr - blackjack
item.description:
This time we‚Äôre going to work on another challenge from pwnable.kr called blackjack - and our goal is to spot the bug in the code.

Solution

In this task we are provided with the code of the blackjack game and a service running on certain port with that game prepared for us. Our goal, in order to get the flag, is to be a millionare - so probably win one million dollars.

Let‚Äôs take a look t the code:

I know it‚Äôs quite long, but jumping in by your own would be very helpful, as it‚Äôs quite trivial bug.

Essentialy, let‚Äôs take a look at this piece.

As you can see, there‚Äôs only one check validating whether or not the player tries to bet more money than he/she has. If you firstly bet the sum bigger than you currently one, the warning will be shown but on the second check, you‚Äôll still be able to bet as much as you can.

See? Now we‚Äôre only need one win ant the challenge will be over.

And here‚Äôs the flag.

Tools

‚Ä¶

References

‚Ä¶

item.title: SharifCTF 2018 - hidden input
item.description:
Another challenge SharifCTF called hidden input.

  • Category: Forensics
  • Points: 50

Solution

At first we are presented with a simple webpage containing 2 inputs - login and password.

But upon inspecting the source code, we can see a hidden input - called debug. After changing its value to 1 and logging in, in addition to the login failed message we can see whole SQL query.

Let‚Äôs construct a simple SQL injection in order to get into the webpage. Firstly, we have to add some value into the password variable, then add ' character to close the previous quotation mark an finally SQL statement that will trick the query OR 1=1;. Last step is to comment out left characters from the original query.

Tools

No external tools used

References

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

item.title: SharifCTF 2018 - hidden
item.description:
Another challenge from SharifCTF called hidden.

  • Category: Forensics
  • Points: 100

Solution

First inspections using the file command does not reveal a lot, but we seem to get what‚Äôs the content of the dump with the strings tool.

As we know that‚Äôs it‚Äôs the memory dump, I decided to run this awesome linux tool for memory dump analysis called Volatility. Firstly I‚Äôll run it with imageinfo option that will show us basic information about the dump.

From that information, the most essential one is the suggested profile WinXPSP2x86, we‚Äôll use it in later analysis. As we have to get the PID of the hidden process, I decided to look into the documentation of this tool and here it is - psxview.

Let‚Äôs run the analysis.

Now we can see that the only process with false value is vmtoolsd.exe with PID 404. The last step is to calculate MD5 hash out of that PID and submit the flag.

SharifCTF{4f4adcbf8c6f66dcfc8a3282ac2bf10a}

Tools

Volatility

References

https://github.com/volatilityfoundation/volatility/wiki/Command-Reference-Mal#psxview

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ceXT9fBGJaI

item.title: SharifCTF 2018 - client01
item.description:
Here we have a challenge from this year SharifCTF called client01.

  • Category: Forensics
  • Points: 75

Solution

As the only thing we get is the home page of some user, I decided to look in for some clues in different places.

As there‚Äôs nothing exciting in this process, let‚Äôs skip to the moment where in .thunderbird/5bd7jhog.default/ImapMail/imap.gmail.com/[Gmail].sbd/ there were still trashed messages talking about uploaded file on filehosting.org

Piece of message from Kosz or Trash.

After visiting the link we have to provide an email address in order to download the file. Instructions are clear, on the provided email we‚Äôll get the download link.

That doesn‚Äôt tell much. Now I decided to take a look at the file using bless hex editor.

If you look closely, you‚Äôll see slightly broken PNG header which is 89 50 4E 47 0D 0A 1A 0A. Let‚Äôs modify ours, by adding value 50, copying the whole hexdump from bless and creating a new file with the copied content.

Tools

Bless Hex Editor

References

https://www.filesignatures.net/index.php?page=search&search=PNG&mode=EXT
